attributes.title: Clinical features of Long QT Syndrome (LQTS) a Review of the literature

summary.value:
Clinical features of Long QT Syndrome (LQTS) a Systematic Review of the literature

Long QT syndrome (LQTS) represents a heterogeneous family of inherited cardiac disorders where heart muscle repolarization and therefore the QT interval on electrocardiogram (ECG) is prolonged. This leads to an increased risk of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, most significantly Torsades des Pointes (TDP) (1). Episodes of arrhythmia may occur at times of emotional or physical stress, resulting in palpitations, syncope and sudden death (1). The prevalence in the population is estimated to range from 1 in 2000-3000 (2, 3). Accurate diagnosis is frequently delayed. In one cohort of long QT patients, 39% of patients had a substantial diagnostic delay despite presenting with seizures and syncope (4). This diagnostic delay is often associated with significant harm; symptomatic patients left without treatment have a high mortality rate, with treatment outcomes are significantly better.
1)	Schwartz PJ, Crotti L, Insolia R. Long-QT syndrome: from genetics to management. Circ Arrhythm Electrophysiol. 2012;5(4):868-77.
2)	Postema PG, et.al. Accurate electrocardiographic assessment of the QT interval: teach the tangent. Heart rhythm. 2008;5(7):1015-8.
3)Hayashi K, et al. Long QT syndrome and associated gene mutation carriers in Japanese children: results from ECG screening examinations. Clinical science . 2009;117(12):415-24.
4) Abrams DJ, Perkin MA, Skinner JR. Long QT syndrome. BMJ 2010;340.


Start Date 25/01/2020

Expected completion 31/10/2020

Review team
Dr William Evans. University of Nottingham Dr Stephen Weng. University of Nottingham
Professor Nadeem Qureshi. University of Nottingham

CoI None

Review Question
P- Eligible participants of any age, excluding prenatal patients, from the general population who access both specialist and/or non-specialist clinical settings with a diagnosis of LQTS.
I-Clinical features to be reported are:
•	Clinical features of LQTS.
•	Other associated clinical features (eg deafness)
C-There are no comparators
O- Documentation clinical features
S- Included studies will be any reports (case reports, case series, registry publications clinical trial reports or cross-sectional studies) which report clinical features.
Limit to publications that described > 10 patients.

Participants/population.
Eligible participants of any age, excluding in utero diagnoses, from the general population who access both specialist and/or non-specialist clinical settings with a diagnosis of LQTS.

Types of Study included
Included studies will be any reports (observational studies, case reports, case series, registry publications,  cross-sectional surveys, and RCTs) which report clinical features.
Limit to publications that described > 10 patients.
(Foreign language, conference abstracts, research letters and papers with <10 participants will be filed seperately for later analysis if there is insufficient information from the included studies).

Data Extraction
Studies will be first screened based on title and abstract by a single reviewer (WE), with 10% of papers assessed by a further reviewer (SW, NQ). Studies that pass this assessment will have their full text screened by two of the same reviewers (WE and SW or NQ), to assess the eligibility for inclusion in the systematic review.
We will extract data in a table using a standardized extraction form. We will capture: study type, location, funding source, participants, LQTS type, number of patients, clinical features described, frequency of clinical feature, if died in study age and cause of death. Discrepancies in data extraction will be resolved through consensus.

Risk of bias assessment
We will be performing a descriptive analysis of the clinical features associated with LQTS, with data extracted from a range of different studies. Consequently there is no single risk of bias tool designed for this purpose. We will use the relevant components of the Downs and Black checklist for measuring study quality:
•	Reporting: Characteristics of those included and those lost to follow up clearly described.
•	External validity: Study subjects representative of the whole population. Was the study centre, and staff present representative of the care the majority of patients would receive.
•	Internal validity (confounding): If there is a control comparator, was the control group taken from the same population as the intervention group.
J Epidemiol Community Health 1998;52:377–384 


Strategy for data synthesis
Aggregation of the occurrence of clinical features, divided by LQTS subtype will be summarised in a table. Considering the nature of the outcome, clinical features, this will be principally a descriptive narrative review. The format of the review report will conform to PRISMA reporting guidance.

Dissemination plans
I intend to publish the review and utilise finding in further research.

attributes.title: ALCOPREJ- MC- Categ Valence
attributes.description: Patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) are suffering from social stigma (Schomerus et al., 2010) relying notably on negative stereotypes concerning their high potential of dangerousness and unpredictability, in particular when compared to other mental disorders (Schomerus et al., 2011). Recent models suggest that AUD patients could also suffer from dehumanization processes (Fontesse et al., 2019) without specifying if dehumanization is expressed through traits (such as uniquely human and human nature traits attributions; dehumanization dual model, Haslam, 2006) or abilities (such as agentism and experience; mind perception model, Gray, Gray, & Wegner 2007) attributions. The present research has two aims. First, dimensions of both stereotypes and dehumanisation (traits and abilities) implied in stigma towards AUD patients will be specified. Second, a target multicategorization strategy (i.e., the use of multiple criteria to categorize others; Crisp & Hewstone, 2007), based either on negatively vs. neutrally vs. positively perceived categorizations, to prevent both processes will be tested. Compared to a control condition, multicategorization conditions should enhance various traits or abilities attributions of people designed as “alcoholic persons” (control < MC- conditions). Fruther, as an exploratory hypothesis, we suggest that multicategorization conditions may enhance gradually various traits or abilities of people designed as “alcoholic persons”, according the category valence implied in the multicategorization condition (MC-NEG < MC-NEU < MC-POS).

question2a.value:
IV :
- multicategorization (MC – Between-subject): categorical variable with 4 levels (control vs. MC negatively vs. neutrally vs. positively perceived categories)

question2b.value:
DV:
- warmth and competence: 3 items per dimension; participants will have to state to what extent the target may have different characteristics. The scale will range from 1 (« not at all ») to 7 (« extremely »).

- uniquely human (UH) and human nature (HN) traits: 3 items per dimension; participant will have to state to what extent the target may have different characteristics. The scale will range from 1 (« not at all ») to 7 (« extremely »).

- agentism and experience:  4 items per dimension; participant will have to state to what extent the target may be capable of different actions. The scale will range from 1 (« barely capable ») to 7 (« highly capable »).

question10b.value:
On arrival in the classroom, participants will be informed of the study and if interested, they will be given an informed consent for their participation. All participants will be naïve to the hypotheses of the experiment. They will be randomly assigned to experimental conditions. Research assistants will thus be blind to each participant condition.
After being exposed to the vignette associated to their condition, participants will have to answer to a questionnaire including Likert-scales asking to what extent:
=> the target is (from 1 “not at all” to 7 “extremely”): mixed warmth and competence measures (“aimable, chaleureux, amical” and “capable, competent, efficace” and mixed uniquely human (UH) and human nature (HN) traits measures (“logique, intelligent, rationnel” and “attentif, curieux, ouvert d’esprit”)
=> the target is able to (from 1 “barely” to 7 ”highly capable”): mixed agentism and experience measures (“planification, auto-contrôle, memorization, moralité” and “douleur, faim, plaisir, peur”).
Afterwards, participants completed a socio-demographic questionnaire before being thanked and debriefed for their participation. 
Complete procedure is approximately around 20 minutes.

question4b.value:
Inclusion rules
 Undergraduate students at the University of Caen Normandy, age greater than or equal to 18 years

Non inclusion rules
Student self-categorizing as presenting an alcohol use disorder.

question5b.value:
Data collection
The data will be collected by two research assistants during classroom sessions. After having completed an informed consent, participants will be randomly assigned to one condition presenting one out of the four vignettes proposed and will be asked to complete the questionnaire associated. Finally, all participants will be thanked (no counterparts provided) and debriefed.

question6b.value:
Considering that 3 contrasts (Helmert format) will be processed following an ANOVA combining repeated measure (e.g. warmth vs. competence) and between factors (multicategorization condition: control vs. MC negatively vs. neutrally vs. positively perceived categories). Gpower calculation was performed for one ANOVA and this result was multiplied by 3 to maintain power even when running the three analyses on the same data. Consequently, based on the GPower calculation (details reported below), 80*3 = 240 participants will be required to obtain a power equivalent to 0.80. 

Analysis: A priori: Compute required sample size 
Input: 
- Effect size f = 0,33 
- α err prob = 0,05 
- Power (1-β err prob) = 0,80
- Number of groups = 4
- Repetitions = 2 
Output: 
- Noncentrality parameter λ = 11.6160000
- Critical F = 2.7249439
- Numerator df = 3
- Denominator df = 76
- Total sample size = 80 
- Actual power = 0.8051627

question7b.value:
Data collection termination rule
Access to groups of students is limited and thus have been negotiated in order to theoretically attain a little more than the required sample size. Questionnaires with these students’ groups will constitute the “termination rule”.

question8b.value:
Exclusion rules
Overly consistent responses
Participants having responded to less than 75% of items.

question1a.value:
Hypotheses - Stigmatization of an “alcoholic” target:
H1: People designed as “alcoholic persons” will be associated with low competence and ambivalent warmth attributions (Stereotype Content Model; Fiske et al., 2002).
H2: People designed as “alcoholic persons” will be associated with low uniquely human and human nature traits attributions (dehumanization dual model; Haslam, 2006).
H3: People designed as “alcoholic persons” will be associated with low agentism and experience attributions (mind perception model; Gray, Gray, & Wegner 2007).
Hypotheses - Efficiency of multicategorization strategy and potential effect of category valence
H4a: Compared to a control condition, multicategorization conditions should enhance both competence and warmth attributions of people designed as “alcoholic persons” (control < MC- conditions)
H4b: As an exploratory hypothesis, we suggest that multicategorization conditions may enhance gradually both competence and warmth attributions of people designed as “alcoholic persons” according the category valence implied in the multicategorization condition (MC-NEG < MC-NEU < MC-POS).
H5a: Compared to a control condition, multicategorization conditions should enhance both uniquely human and human nature traits of people designed as “alcoholic persons”.
H5b: As an exploratory hypothesis, we suggest that multicategorization conditions may enhance gradually both uniquely human and human nature traits of people designed as “alcoholic persons”, according the category valence implied in the multicategorization condition (MC-NEG < MC-NEU < MC-POS).
H6a: Compared to a control condition, multicategorization conditions should enhance both agentism and experience of people designed as “alcoholic persons”.
H6b: As an exploratory hypothesis, we suggest that multicategorization conditions may enhance gradually both agentism and experience of people designed as “alcoholic persons”, according the category valence implied in the multicategorization condition (MC-NEG < MC-NEU < MC-POS).

question2a.value: No specific expectations on possible interactions

question3a.value: Considering our experimental procedure based on a vignette study, no manipulation checks are required.

question1c.value: After a consistency reliability check (Cronbach ‘s alpha > .65, if lower, item could be removed) for each measure, a score will be computed for competence and warmth.

question2c.value: To test H1, H4a and b, a first repeated ANOVA will be performed.

question3c.value:
To test H1, H4a and b, a first repeated ANOVA will be performed with stereotype traits (competence vs. warmth) as a within-subject factor and multicategorization (MC) condition as between-subject factor.  
To specifically put H1 to test, comparison to a standard threshold (scale neutral point) will be processed for each mean value of control condition only.
To arbitrate between H4a and b, Helmert contrasts will be performed on data. 
The first contrast (C1) will compare the control condition (coded -3) to all MC conditions (coded +1 for each). 
The second contrast (C2) will compare the negative MC condition (coded -2) to neutral and positive MC conditions (coded +1 for each). 
The third contrast (C3) will compare the neutral MC condition (coded -1) to the positive MC condition (coded +1).

If only C1 is significant, H4a will thus be validated.
If all contrasts are significant, H4b will thus be validated.

question1c.value: After a consistency reliability check (Cronbach ‘s alpha > .65, if lower, item could be removed) for each measure, a score will be computed for agentism and experience abilities.

question2c.value: To test H2, H5a and b, a second repeated ANOVA will be performed.

question3c.value:
To test H2, H5a and b, a second repeated ANOVA will be performed with humanization abilities (agentism vs. experience) as a within-subject factor and multicategorization (MC) condition as between-subject factor.  
To specifically put H3 to test, comparison to a standard threshold (scale neutral point) will be processed for each mean value of control condition only.
To arbitrate between H6a and b, Helmert contrasts will be performed on data. 
The first contrast (C1) will compare the control condition (coded -3) to all MC conditions (coded +1 for each). 
The second contrast (C2) will compare the negative MC condition (coded -2) to neutral and positive MC conditions (coded +1 for each). 
The third contrast (C3) will compare the neutral MC condition (coded -1) to the positive MC condition (coded +1).


If only C1 is significant, H4A will thus be validated.
If all contrasts are significant, H4b will thus be validated.

question1c.value: After a consistency reliability check (Cronbach ‘s alpha > .65, if lower, item could be removed) for each measure, a score will be computed for UH traits and HN traits.

question2c.value: To test H2, H5a and b, a second repeated ANOVA will be performed.

attributes.title: ALCOPREJ - MC - Categ Number
attributes.description: Patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) are suffering from social stigma (Schomerus et al., 2010) relying notably on negative stereotypes concerning their high potential of dangerousness and unpredictability notably compared to other mental disorders (Schomerus et al., 2011). Recent models suggest that AUD patients could also suffer from dehumanization processes (Fontesse et al., 2019) without specifying if dehumanization is expressed through traits (such as uniquely human and human nature traits attributions; dehumanization dual model, Haslam, 2006) or abilities (such as agentism and experience; mind perception model, Gray, Gray, & Wegner 2007) attributions. The present research has two aims. First, dimensions of both stereotypes and dehumanisation (traits and abilities) implied in stigma towards AUD patients will be specified. Second, a target multicategorization strategy (i.e., the use of multiple criteria to categorize others; Crisp & Hewstone, 2007), based either on 3 vs. 5 vs. 7 categorizations, to prevent both processes will be tested. Following Halford et al. (2005) demonstrating that people have difficulties to process combination of more than 4 categories, we hypothesize that below 5 categories included, multicategorization process will not perform to enhance intergroup perception. A 7-categories multicategorization condition is included to explore the possibility (or not) to enhance multicategorization efficiency by increasing the complexity of combinations. No element allows us to drive a specific hypothesis on this point.

Hypotheses - Stigmatization of an “alcoholic” target:
H1: People designed as “alcoholic persons” will be associated with low competence and ambivalent warmth attributions (Stereotype Content Model; Fiske et al., 2002).
H2: People designed as “alcoholic persons” will be associated with low uniquely human and human nature traits attributions (dehumanization dual model; Haslam, 2006).
H3: People designed as “alcoholic persons” will be associated with low agentism and experience attributions (mind perception model; Gray, Gray, & Wegner 2007).
Hypotheses - Efficiency of Multicategorization Strategy
H4: Compared to a control condition and a multicategorization condition including only 3 categories, multicategorization conditions including either 5 categories or more should enhance both competence and warmth attributions of people designed as “alcoholic persons”.
H5: Compared to a control condition and a multicategorization condition including only 3 categories, multicategorization conditions including either 5 categories or more should enhance both uniquely human and human nature traits of people designed as “alcoholic persons”.
H6: Compared to a control condition and a multicategorization condition including only 3 categories, multicategorization conditions including either 5 categories or more should enhance both agentism and experience of people designed as “alcoholic persons”.

question2a.value: No specific expectations on possible interactions

question3a.value: Considering our experimental procedure based on a vignette study, no manipulation checks are required.

question5a.value: Patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) are suffering from social stigma (Schomerus et al., 2010) relying notably on negative stereotypes concerning their high potential of dangerousness and unpredictability notably compared to other mental disorders (Schomerus et al., 2011). Recent models suggest that AUD patients could also suffer from dehumanization processes (Fontesse et al., 2019) without specifying if dehumanization is expressed through traits (such as uniquely human and human nature traits attributions; dehumanization dual model, Haslam, 2006) or abilities (such as agentism and experience; mind perception model, Gray, Gray, & Wegner 2007) attributions. The present research has two aims. First, dimensions of both stereotypes and dehumanisation (traits and abilities) implied in stigma towards AUD patients will be specified. Second, a target multicategorization strategy (i.e., the multiple criteria to categorize others; Crisp & Hewstone, 2007), based either on 3 vs. 5 vs. 7 categorizations, to prevent both processes will be tested. Following Halford et al. (2005) demonstrating that people have difficulties to process combination of more than 4 categories, we hypothesize that below 5 categories included, multicategorization process will not perform to enhance intergroup perception. A 7-categories multicategorization condition is included to explore the possibility (or not) to enhance multicategorization efficiency by increasing the complexity of combinations. No element allows us to drive a specific hypothesis on this point.

To specifically put H1 to test, comparison to a standard threshold (scale neutral point) will be processed for each mean value of control condition only.
To specifically put H4 to test, repeated contrasts will be performed on the data.
The first contrast (C1) will compare the control condition to 3-categories-MC condition. 
The second contrast (C2) will compare the 3-categories-MC condition to the 5-categories-MC condition.
The third contrast (C3) will compare the 5-categories-MC condition to the 7-categories-MC condition.

H4 will be considered as validated if C1 is non significant and C2 is significant. No specific hypothesis is expected on C3.

attributes.title: Improving the usefulness of evidence concerning the effectiveness of implementation strategies for knowledge products in primary healthcare: a series of systematic reviews

summary.value:
Background: The literature on the implementation of knowledge products is extensive. However, this literature is still difficult to interpret for policymakers and other stakeholders when faced with choosing implementation strategies likely to bring about successful change in their health systems. This work has the particularity to examine the scope of this literature, and to clarify the effectiveness of implementation strategies for different knowledge products. Consequently, we aim to: 1) determine the strengths and weaknesses of existing literature overviews; 2) produce a detailed portrait of the literature on implementation strategies for various knowledge products; and 3) assess the effectiveness of implementation strategies for each knowledge product identified and classify them.
Methods: We will use a three-phase approach consisting of a critical analysis of existing literature overviews, a systematic review of systematic reviews, and a series of systematic reviews and meta-analyses. We will follow the Cochrane Methodology for each of three phases. Our eligibility criteria are defined following a PICOS approach: Population, individuals or stakeholders participating in healthcare delivery, specifically, healthcare providers, caregivers, and end users; Intervention, any type of strategy aiming to implement a knowledge product including, but not limited to, a decision support tool, a clinical practice guideline, a policy brief, or a decision-making tool, a one-pager, or a health intervention; Comparison, any comparator will be considered; Outcomes, Phases 1 and 2 – any outcome related to implementation strategies including, but not limited to, the measures of adherence/fidelity to the use of knowledge products, their acceptability, adoption, appropriateness, feasibility, adaptability, implementation costs, penetration/reach and sustainability; Phase 3 – any additional outcome related to patients (psychosocial, health behavioral, and clinical outcomes) or healthcare professionals (behavioral and performance outcomes); Setting, primary healthcare has to be covered. For each phase, two reviewers will independently perform the selection of studies, data extraction, and assess their methodological quality. We will analyze extracted data, and perform narrative syntheses and meta-analyses when possible.
Discussion: Our results could inform not only the overviews’ methodology, but also the development of an online platform for the implementation strategies of knowledge products. This platform could be useful for stakeholders in implementation science.

attributes.title: The domain-specificity and generality of prestige-biased social learning

q1.value: The domain-specificity and generality of prestige-biased social learning

q2.value: Charlotte Olivia Brand, Alex Mesoudi, Tom Morgan

q3.value:
Prestige-biased social learning occurs when individuals preferentially copy beneficial knowledge or skills from specific individuals who have been observed being copied by others, being attended to by others, or generally receiving freely conferred deference from others (Henrich & Gil-White 2001). These individuals are said to have ‘prestige’. Prestige-biased social learning has been proposed as an adaptive social learning strategy as it provides an efficient short-cut to acquiring adaptive social information when more direct means (e.g. identifying and copying successful skills/knowledge, or highly skilled/knowledgeable individuals) are unavailable or costly (Henrich & Gil-White 2001). Consistent with this claim, previous experimental work shows that participants will use prestige-information when selecting a model to socially learn from, but only when a) the prestige-information is tied to success and b) direct success information is unavailable (Brand et al. submitted). 
However, the domain-specificity or generality of prestige-bias remains little understood. We suggest that domain general prestige-biased social learning will be adaptive when the domains that are being generalised over are correlated with an underlying trait in which other individuals are successful. 

Here we present a task which contains quiz questions from explicitly different topics: weight estimation, world geography, art history, and language identification. Although an underlying trait such as general intelligence, (or “g”), or educational attainment may lead to success across these domains, we specifically tailored the categories to be as unrelated to formal educational curriculums as possible and more closely related to life experience, such as weight estimating (rather than Maths attainment), or language identification (rather than English attainment). A previous experiment using the same quiz and topics found medium to strong correlations between the asocial topic scores, (R2 between 0.2 and 0.48), thus using cross-domain and domain-general information is indicative of score on the current topic, but includes added noise compared to domain-specific scores. Correlations within asocial topic scores were much more strongly correlated across the two rounds (R2 between 0.3 and 0.6), than between asocial topic scores (R2 between 0.06 and 0.36).

q4.value:
Given that domain-specific prestige should be most highly correlated with score on the topic being answered (confirmed by a previous experiment), and that cross-domain prestige will be least correlated with score on the topic being answered, we hypothesise that: 

Hypotheses:
1.	Domain-specific prestige bias will be employed more often than cross-domain prestige bias (Condition A) and domain-general prestige bias (Condition C)
2.	Domain-general prestige bias will be employed more often that cross-domain prestige bias (Condition B). 
3.	Cross-domain prestige bias is only employed when access to domain-general or domain-specific prestige information is not available.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants are grouped into ten groups of ten, into three conditions. Participants are answering quiz questions on four different topics. 
Within the first 60 questions of the quiz (Round 1), participants can choose to copy other participants’ answers based on their scores on the current topic. In the subsequent 40 questions (Round 2) participants are then provided with a choice of information about the other participants that they can see if they choose to copy someone else. These include domain-specific prestige (number of times copied in Round 1 on the current topic), domain-general prestige (number of times copied in Round 1 overall) or cross-domain prestige (number of times copied in Round 1 on a different topic to the one being answered). 
See attached for full details.

q9.value: We run the three conditions in a random order on subsequent days to randomise the participants assigned to each condition. We are also randomly sampling from a large participant pool.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are using Dallinger, an automated participant recruitment programme which recruits participants from MTurk.

q13.value: To allow for a large enough sample of copying behaviour, based on our previous experiment using the same quiz questions, we will recruit ten groups of ten participants for each condition (n=300 altogether).

q14.value: This is based on our previous study which provided us a large sample of copying instances to analysed. It is also somewhat restricted by participant fees.

q15.value: We will stop recruiting once we have recruited ten groups for each condition, each group can have no fewer than 5 individuals completing the quiz at once.

question.value: We are manipulating the information that participants are able to view about each other when copying in the second round. Each condition provides the participants with a choice of information, domain-specific prestige versus cross-domain prestige (Condition A), domain-general versus cross-domain prestige (Condition B), or domain-general versus domain-specific prestige (Condition C). See attached for full details.

We will measure participants' score on each question (0 or 1), whether they chose to copy or not (0 or 1) and in Round 2, what information they chose to copy (cross-domain, domain-general, or domain-specific). We will be recording which group participants are part of, and which condition they are in. This will provide us with everything we need for the full analyses.
We will be using multi-level Bayesian models using Richard McElreath's Rethinking package. Please see attached for full details.

q21.value: We will be using 89% credible intervals as is default in the Rethinking package in R (McElreath 2016).

q22.value: If any participant's answers are tagged with "human=False" for over half of the questions, this suggests the participant was not paying attention as their timer timed out for over half the questions (we have attention checks at each round break, which then excludes people from continuing automatically if not passed- so this is only applicable within rounds).

q24.value: These are detailed as "follow-up analyses" in the attached file. We may also explore if there is an effect of gender, as previous studies have found women can rely on social information more than men in some circumstances (e.g. low confidence/ high risk).

We suggest that domain general prestige-biased social learning will be adaptive when the domains that are being generalised over are correlated with an underlying trait in which other individuals are successful. 

Here we present a task which contains quiz questions from explicitly different topics: weight estimation, world geography, art history, and language identification. Although an underlying trait such as general intelligence, (or “g”), or educational attainment may lead to success across these domains, we specifically tailored the categories to be as unrelated to formal educational curriculums as possible and more closely related to life experience, such as weight estimating (rather than Maths attainment), or language identification (rather than English attainment). A previous experiment using the same quiz and topics found medium to strong correlations between the asocial topic scores, (R2 between 0.2 and 0.48), thus using cross-domain and domain-general information is indicative of score on the current topic, but includes added noise compared to domain-specific scores. Correlations within asocial topic scores were much more strongly correlated across the two rounds (R2 between 0.3 and 0.6), than between asocial topic scores (R2 between 0.06 and 0.36).
registration_responses.q4:
Given that domain-specific prestige should be most highly correlated with score on the topic being answered (confirmed by a previous experiment), and that cross-domain prestige will be least correlated with score on the topic being answered, we hypothesise that: 

Hypotheses:
1.	Domain-specific prestige bias will be employed more often than cross-domain prestige bias (Condition A) and domain-general prestige bias (Condition C)
2.	Domain-general prestige bias will be employed more often that cross-domain prestige bias (Condition B). 
3.	Cross-domain prestige bias is only employed when access to domain-general or domain-specific prestige information is not available.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: We run the three conditions in a random order on subsequent days to randomise the participants assigned to each condition. We are also randomly sampling from a large participant pool.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: To allow for a large enough sample of copying behaviour, based on our previous experiment using the same quiz questions, we will recruit ten groups of ten participants for each condition (n=300 altogether).
registration_responses.q14: This is based on our previous study which provided us a large sample of copying instances to analysed. It is also somewhat restricted by participant fees.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop recruiting once we have recruited ten groups for each condition, each group can have no fewer than 5 individuals completing the quiz at once.
registration_responses.q21: We will be using 89% credible intervals as is default in the Rethinking package in R (McElreath 2016).
registration_responses.q22: If any participant's answers are tagged with "human=False" for over half of the questions, this suggests the participant was not paying attention as their timer timed out for over half the questions (we have attention checks at each round break, which then excludes people from continuing automatically if not passed- so this is only applicable within rounds).
registration_responses.q24: These are detailed as "follow-up analyses" in the attached file. We may also explore if there is an effect of gender, as previous studies have found women can rely on social information more than men in some circumstances (e.g. low confidence/ high risk).
registration_responses.q8.question:
Participants are grouped into ten groups of ten, into three conditions. Participants are answering quiz questions on four different topics. 
Within the first 60 questions of the quiz (Round 1), participants can choose to copy other participants’ answers based on their scores on the current topic. In the subsequent 40 questions (Round 2) participants are then provided with a choice of information about the other participants that they can see if they choose to copy someone else. These include domain-specific prestige (number of times copied in Round 1 on the current topic), domain-general prestige (number of times copied in Round 1 overall) or cross-domain prestige (number of times copied in Round 1 on a different topic to the one being answered). 
See attached for full details.
registration_responses.q12.question: We are using Dallinger, an automated participant recruitment programme which recruits participants from MTurk.
registration_responses.q16.question: We are manipulating the information that participants are able to view about each other when copying in the second round. Each condition provides the participants with a choice of information, domain-specific prestige versus cross-domain prestige (Condition A), domain-general versus cross-domain prestige (Condition B), or domain-general versus domain-specific prestige (Condition C). See attached for full details.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure participants' score on each question (0 or 1), whether they chose to copy or not (0 or 1) and in Round 2, what information they chose to copy (cross-domain, domain-general, or domain-specific). We will be recording which group participants are part of, and which condition they are in. This will provide us with everything we need for the full analyses.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will be using multi-level Bayesian models using Richard McElreath's Rethinking package. Please see attached for full details.

attributes.title: Personality and Favourite Activities Study (project code name: KOBE)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value:
Using G*Power software, the following parameters were specified for the analysis of this research: Correlation, tail(s) = one, effect size = 0.2 (small to medium, and most common in psychology – see Funder & Ozer, 2019), alpha = .05, power = .95. This yielded a required sample size of 262.

To account for potential data exclusions based on dishonest responding and outliers, we will recruit an additional 5% of participants, yielding a targeted sample size of 276 (262* 1.05).  We will therefore aim to recruit a minimum of 276 participants.

analyses.value: The main hypothesis will be tested using correlation analysis.  Correlations will be computed between each measure of openness to experience and the number of passions using (a) passion criteria scores and (b) freely-reported responses.  We anticipate that both openness scores will positively correlate with both measures of passion quantity.  Directional, one-tailed significance tests will be computed.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from all analyses if they report that they did not answer the items honestly (as part of the honesty-check item at the end of the survey).

Potential univariate outliers will be identified using Z-scores (≥ 3.29).  Potential multivariate outliers will be identified using Mahalanobis distance scores (≥ 13.816, df = 2, p < .001). We will explore if excluding these potential outliers changes the results in any meaningful way.  

Policy regarding other data exclusions is written in our lab’s Standard Operating Procedure.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variable will be the number of passionate activities people have in their lives.  This will be calculated using two methods: 

(1) Participants will report their four favourite activities in their lives and respond to 5 questions assessing the passion criteria (Vallerand et al., 2003) for each activity.  An activity will be classified as a passionate activity if the average passion criteria score is equal to or greater than 5 (on a 7-point scale); this classification procedure is in line with previous research categorizing passionate and non-passionate activities (Philippe et al., 2009; Schellenberg & Bailis, 2015).  Using this method, each participant will be classified as having between 0 and 4 passionate activities.

(2) Participants will answer a single question assessing the number of passionate activities they have in their lives: “This survey focused on activities in people’s lives toward which they are passionate.  These are activities that people like, find important, are part of their identity, and in which they spend a significant amount of time and energy.  How many activities would you say you engage in that you would classify as a passion?”  Participants will type the number of passionate activities they have in a text box.  Using this method, there are no limitations on the number of passionate activities that can be reported.

Openness to experience (the independent variable) will also be measured using two methods:

(1) Two items from the openness subscale of the Ten Item Personality Inventory (Gosling et al., 2003).  This short assessment of openness will be included in order to replicate relationships that we have observed in previous research on this topic. An overall openness score will be calculated by averaging both items (after reverse-scoring the appropriate item).

(2) Items from the 120-item version of the International Personality Item Pool (IPIP) NEO (see Johnson, 2014; Maples et al., 2014).  Only the 24-item subscale assessing openness to experience will be assessed.  An overall openness score will be calculated by averaging all subscale items (after reverse-scoring the appropriate items).

We expect that both measures of openness will be positively correlated with both measures of passion quantity.

conditions.value: There are no experimental conditions in this study.

hypothesis.value: Is the personality trait openness to experience related to the number of passionate activities people have in their lives?  We predict that scores on openness will be positively correlated with the number of reported passionate activities.

q1.value: Perceptual Biases in Body Size Estimation - Slider Experiment

q2.value: Robert Lachlan, Ozge Cengiz, isabelle mareschal, Daniela Zigova, Marilena Ouzouni, Kiran Malhan, Anandini Kistamah, Katie Knighton, Nazuk Chopra

q3.value: Perceptual biases have been suggested to influence our judgement of body size, but previous studies have not found evidence for a clear directional bias in how we perceive others' body size. We will measure whether participants underestimate the size of a body they have just seen, and will investigate whether such biases are influenced by social media usage, exposure to thin bodies and body satisfaction.

q4.value:
(1) Participants show a bias towards underestimating body size
(2) Participants show a greater bias if they use social media (Instagram) more
(3) Participants show a greater bias when their ethnicity doesn't match that of the body they are assessing.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will carry out a body size matching task on a tablet. They will match the size of an computer-generated image to a target they have seen briefly. The matching will involve using a slider that varies body size along a scale (1-100). The difference between target and selected size will be a measure of "perceptual bias". Each participant will carry out 10 trials, with different target body sizes (which is the first variable). This will be a mixed design since participants will be asked about their Instagram usage (6 factors), and ethnicity.

q9.value: Target body size will be randomized by simple randomization. Model identity (including ethnicity) will be randomized by simple randomization. There are 10 sets of models (each differing in clothing, skin tone, hair style etc), and 10 start ranges for each model.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited on Royal Holloway campus by approaching them in public areas. Participants must be at least 18 years old, and female.

q14.value: The experimental method is novel enough that effect sizes are not easily predictable. Our sample size is estimated roughly from pilot data.

question.value: The target model size varies on a scale from 10 to 90. Each participant will carry out one trial at each decile of this range, with the actual target size selected randomly from within that decile (e.g. 10-18, 18-26 etc).

We will ask 6 questions about Instagram use:
(1) How much time on average do you spend on Instagram per day?
(2) Do you follow only profiles of people you know on Instagram (i.e. friends and acquaintances, NOT celebrities)? (Yes/No)
(3) Do you follow more celebrity or public figures, in relation to profiles of people you know, on Instagram? (Yes/No)
(4) Do you edit pictures of yourself before you post them on Instagram? (Never, Rarely, Sometimes, Often, Always)
(5) How often do you post pictures of yourself on Instagram? (Never, Rarely, Sometimes, Often, Always)
(6) How important is the number of followers you have on Instagram to you, on a scale of 1-5, with 5 being most important?

We will ask individuals to report their ethnicity ("Black (Black British, Caribbean, African etc)", "East Asian (Chinese, Japanese, Korean etc)", "South Asian (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi etc)", "White (White British, White European etc)", "Mixed/Other", "Prefer not to answer")
For each trial, we will also record whether or not participant ethnicity matches the image ethnicity.

The response variable will be the difference between target and selected image size. Since the image size scale is bounded (1-100), we will consider transforming these sizes (e.g. logistic) particularly if differences are very large and don't approximate a normal distribution.
We will subject the Instagram usage responses to polychoric factor analysis.

We will use mixed effect regression using lmer or MCMCglmm in R. The response variable will be difference between target and chosen image. The fixed effects will be Model size, model ethnicity, participant ethnicity, ethnicity match, and the six Instagram variables, or output of the factor analysis if it suggests strong correlation between the variables. The random effect will be participant id. Interactions between Model size and other predictor variables will be investigated.

q20.value:
The difference score measured is bounded by the body size scale we are using (1-100). If accuracies are low, this may lead to departures from normality. If that is the case, we will consider using logistic transformation of the model size and selected scores.
Instagram time use may require square root transformation to approximate a uniform distribution.

q21.value: We will use standard p<0.05 criteria. Our tests are two-tailed.

q23.value: Participants who do not move the slider during the trials will be excluded from the analysis

attributes.title: Anxiety as a Risk Factor for Compulsive Sexual Behaviour Disorder: A Systematic Review
attributes.description: Systematic review of studies looking at anxiety as a correlate or risk factor for Compulsive Sexual Behavior DIsorder.

summary.value:
Compulsive Sexual Behaviour Disorder (CSBD) is recognized as a diagnosis in the ICD-11, but as of 2013, when the previous Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM-5) was published, it did not have enough research backing to be recognized as a diagnosis. Previous research notes the particular importance of CSBD in health psychology given its relationship to HIV and risky sexual behaviours (Miner & Coleman, 2013), as well as similarities with addictive disorders (Kraus, Voon, & Potenza, 2016). Increasing work has been completed on this disorder, particularly focused on risk factors and treatment (e.g. Blycker & Potenza, 2018; Hallberg, Kaldo, Arver, Dhejne, & Oberg, 2017; Parsons, Rendina, Moody, Ventuneac, & Grov, 2015). One of the main aims of such research is to understand which factors may precipitate CSBD, and whether certain models may explain this. One such model is the Pathways Model from Gambling Disorder (Blaszczynski & Nower, 2002), which suggests that Gambling Disorder occurs through three pathways: behavioural conditioning; behavioural conditioning and emotional vulnerability; and behavioural conditioning, emotional vulnerability, and antisocial/impulsive characteristics. To understand whether this model would also fit for CSBD it is important to understand which emotional vulnerabilities may be at play and how much they may affect this disorder. Research suggests that anxiety may be one such important risk factor.
A recent meta-analysis (N = 95) showed that anxiety was one of the strongest significant syndemic indicators of sexual compulsivity (Rooney, Tulloch, & Blashill, 2018). These results highlight the potential negative associations between anxiety and CSBD, and, when looked at alongside the Pathways Model, suggest that anxiety may be a significant emotional vulnerability factor that may perpetuate compulsive sexual behaviour. However, it focused solely on men who have male sexual partners. Another review focused on childhood sexual abuse and trauma (closely linked to anxiety symptoms) as a risk factor for CSBD (Slavin, Scoglio, Blycker, Potenza, & Kraus, 2020). The authors noted that there was overall support for child sexual abuse as a risk factor for CSBD and opined that this relationship may be affected by other forms of trauma or that other types of trauma may have a stronger relationship. This suggests that anxiety, as a major component of trauma, may also be a risk factor for CSBD.
Therefore, this systematic review aims to understand whether the current literature lends support to anxiety, focused on those with a diagnosis of an anxiety disorder, as a risk factor for CSBD in adults and adolescents.
Method
To complete this systematic review, the following steps will be completed by the author, and other members of the SPARTA lab (no review protocol was completed):
•	Conduct a search of PsychInfo (1887 to current) and PubMed (1950’s to present) with the following search terms:
o	"sex addiction”, “hypersexuality”, “hypersexual behavior”, “hypersexual disorder”, “hypersexual*”, “pornography addiction”, “compulsive sexual behavior”, “sexual compulsivity”, or “sex* addiction”, alongside "anxiety", "panic", or "phobia"
o	Remove any duplicate studies
o	All studies found will be saved in Mendeley Reference Manager
	An initial search produced 112 hits from PubMed and 232 hits from PsychInfo. After duplicates were removed this left a combined hit total of 273 articles.
•	Conduct a review of titles and abstracts for inclusion/exclusion using the following criteria (if unsure, the study will be included for full text review):
o	Inclusion
	Any time period
•	Rationale: To ensure that all relevant studies are captured.
	Study measures compulsive sexual behaviour (CSB; also known as hypersexuality, sex addiction, and pornography addiction) in participant
•	Rationale: This is to ensure that the relationship between CSB and anxiety can be measured and compared.
	At least one group of participants are identified as having clinically significant problems with CSB
•	Rationale: This is the population of interest, which ensures that these individuals are experiencing these symptoms.
	Study measures levels of an anxiety disorder (according to DSM-V) or general anxiety level of participant
•	Rationale: This is to ensure that the relationship between CSB and anxiety can be measured and compared.
	Study is available in English
•	Rationale: Author is only able to read English
	Study reports a value for the relationship between the CSB and anxiety measures (summary measures)
•	The value may be a percentage, statistic (e.g. r) or number of participants
o	Given the diversity of methods in the area of research, selecting based on summary statistic is not feasible.
•	Rationale: This allows for comparisons between studies.
	Study is quantitative
•	Including cross-sectional and longitudinal data
•	Rationale: This is to ensure that the relationship between CSB and anxiety can be measured and compared.
•	Conference presentations, unpublished work, and dissertations will be reviewed if accessible and found throughout this search process
o	Exclusion
	Previous meta-analysis or review
•	Rationale: To ensure that no studies are included more than once
	Books or book chapter
•	Rationale: To ensure no studies are included more than once.
•	Conduct a review of full text using the same inclusion/exclusion criteria
o	If full text is not available, contact the author and request a copy
	This will be attempted only once
•	Review references of remaining studies to identify further potentially useful studies
o	If any are identified review these according to the same procedure detailed above
•	Remaining studies will be thoroughly read again, and data extracted
o	See Table 1 for list of variables to extract
o	Data will be inputted into a excel spreadsheet which includes each of the variables as a separate column heading
o	If data is not available, authors will be contacted
•	Qualitative analysis of articles
o	Studies will be summarized and discussed in terms of:
	Anxiety disorder measured
	Methodology
	Sample Characteristics
	Other groups may be discussed if larger themes emerge
o	No meta-analysis will be conducted due to a wide variety of methodology within this area of research
o	Summaries of this will be presented in Table 2.
o	Bias of studies will also be evaluated according to the Cochrane Criteria for judging risk of bias in the ‘Risk of bias’ assessment tool and will be noted if considered “high risk” or “unsure risk”, particularly in terms of:
	Incomplete outcome data
	Selective reporting
	Other bias

See attached for full proposal.

•	Rationale: This is the population of interest, which ensures that these individuals are experiencing these symptoms.
	Study measures levels of an anxiety disorder (according to DSM-V) or general anxiety level of participant
•	Rationale: This is to ensure that the relationship between CSB and anxiety can be measured and compared.
	Study is available in English
•	Rationale: Author is only able to read English
	Study reports a value for the relationship between the CSB and anxiety measures (summary measures)
•	The value may be a percentage, statistic (e.g. r) or number of participants
o	Given the diversity of methods in the area of research, selecting based on summary statistic is not feasible.
•	Rationale: This allows for comparisons between studies.
	Study is quantitative
•	Including cross-sectional and longitudinal data
•	Rationale: This is to ensure that the relationship between CSB and anxiety can be measured and compared.
•	Conference presentations, unpublished work, and dissertations will be reviewed if accessible and found throughout this search process
o	Exclusion
	Previous meta-analysis or review
•	Rationale: To ensure that no studies are included more than once
	Books or book chapter
•	Rationale: To ensure no studies are included more than once.
•	Conduct a review of full text using the same inclusion/exclusion criteria
o	If full text is not available, contact the author and request a copy
	This will be attempted only once
•	Review references of remaining studies to identify further potentially useful studies
o	If any are identified review these according to the same procedure detailed above
•	Remaining studies will be thoroughly read again, and data extracted
o	See Table 1 for list of variables to extract
o	Data will be inputted into a excel spreadsheet which includes each of the variables as a separate column heading
o	If data is not available, authors will be contacted
•	Qualitative analysis of articles
o	Studies will be summarized and discussed in terms of:
	Anxiety disorder measured
	Methodology
	Sample Characteristics
	Other groups may be discussed if larger themes emerge
o	No meta-analysis will be conducted due to a wide variety of methodology within this area of research
o	Summaries of this will be presented in Table 2.
o	Bias of studies will also be evaluated according to the Cochrane Criteria for judging risk of bias in the ‘Risk of bias’ assessment tool and will be noted if considered “high risk” or “unsure risk”, particularly in terms of:
	Incomplete outcome data
	Selective reporting
	Other bias

See attached for full proposal.

q1.value: Perceptual biases in body size estimation

q2.value: Robert Lachlan, Ozge Cengiz, Isabelle Mareschal, Daniela Zigova, Marilena Ouzouni, Kiran Malhan, Anandini Kistamah, Katie Knighton, Nazuk Chopra

q3.value: Perceptual biases have been suggested to influence our judgement of body size, but previous studies have not found evidence for a clear directional bias in how we perceive others' body size. We will measure whether participants underestimate the size of a body they have just seen, and will investigate whether such biases are influenced by social media usage, exposure to thin bodies and body satisfaction.

q4.value:
Participants underestimate the size of a body they have just seen. Directional (selected body size will be smaller than model size).
Participants that have more exposure to social media (specifically Instagram) will show a stronger tendency to underestimate size (Directional)
Participants that show less body satisfaction will show a stronger tendency to underestimate body size (Directional).
Participants will show a weaker bias for bodies of the same ethnicity as themselves (Directional).
Participants will show a stronger bias if they have been exposed to thin-ideal images, and a weaker bias if exposed to body-positive images compared to exposure to controls (Directional).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Based on one experimental factor, participants will be assigned to three groups (Thin, Body positive and control images). We will also collect information about participants' Instagram usage and their body satisfaction.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from advertisements on social media and in the department. If this is insufficient to recruit our sample size, we will use online recruitment tools (Mechanical Turk or similar). Rewards will be entry into a £25 draw for an Amazon token. Participants must identify as female, be at least 18 years old and have normal or corrected vision.

q14.value: Our methods are new enough to render power analysis ineffective. We estimated 300 participants on the basis of pilot data.

question.value:
(1) We manipulated images shown to participants before our perceptual task. Group 1 observed 6 images from a "fitspiration" pool. Group 2 observed 6 images from a "body positive" pool. Group 3 (controls) observed 6 images of dogs.
(2) Each participant will carry out 10 trials of the perceptual task. In each trial, the target image will be of a different size on a scale of 10-90. There will be one exemplar drawn randomly from each decile of the scale (i.e. one between 10 and 18, one between 18 and 26 etc).

(1) Instagram usage. The estimated average time spent on Instagram per day.
(2) Body Appreciation scale. We will ask four questions from the Body Appreciation Scale 2. I feel good about my body, I take a positive attitude towards my body, I appreciate the different and unique characteristics of my body, I feel like I am beautiful even if I am different from media images of attractive people (e.g., models, actresses/actors). Answers are on a five point scale (Never, Rarely, Sometimes, Often, Always).
(3) Image Likes. During the Image Presentation phase, participants will be asked whether or not they would "like" an image. The total number of likes (out of 6) will be calculated.
(4) Difference Score. The response variable will be which of four images are selected. These are ordered to differ by -9, -3, +3 and +6 on the 100-point scale from the target presented image.
Body Appreciation Scale answers will be summed to provide an overall score of body appreciation.

We will use Ordinal Mixed Effects regression using R package MCMCglmm. Difference Score will be the response variable. Fixed effect variables will be: Experimental Group, Number of likes, Interaction between likes and group, body appreciation score, instagram usage (based on previous experience, this may be Square-root or log transformed, whichever is most appropriate to generate an approximately uniform distribution), Model image size. The random effect will be participant ID.

In R, the prior will be specified as:
priorOrd=list(R=list(V=1, fix=1), G=list(G1=list(V=1, nu=0)))
The model will specified as:
mcm1<-MCMCglmm(Diff ~ TargetSize+Group*Likes+BAS+Instagram, random= ~Participant, data=d1, family="ordinal", prior=priorOrd, nitt=100000, burnin=10000, verbose = FALSE)
MCMC generations and burnin will be adjusted as necessary to achieve good MCMC results.

In addition, we will explore possible interactions between TargetSize and the other fixed effects.
